thread.section_title: Business News, Economy, Finance & ASX Market News
thread.title: Residential trusts shrug off mortgage re-pricing
thread.title_full: Residential trusts shrug off mortgage re-pricing

title: Residential trusts shrug off mortgage re-pricing
text:
17-23 Mitchell Avenue and 78 Sutherland Road, Jannali, comprising 5 detached residential dwellings situated on a site area of 4143 sqm.
Mortgage re-pricing that occurred with Westpac lifting its variable rate, could trigger other banks to follow suit, which may have a longer term impact on the residential Australian real estate industrial trusts and also stall retail sales growth, according to market analysts.
While any big jumps in home loans are not predicted in the short to medium term, those in the firing line include Lend Lease, Mirvac, Stockland and Frasers Australia.
But talk of a price collapse has been dismissed by the AREIT managers, with all of them repeating that the rate of growth could slow, but not demand.
The residential-focussed AREITs have all forecast that the housing market will underpin earnings in the coming year.
Advertisement Morgan Stanley analysts said interest rates are the dominant driver of house prices, and house price growth is the key driver of Mirvac and Stockland's relative funds from operations multiple.
"Hence rising rates have historically resulted in a de-rating or underperformance," the analysts said.
At the Lend Lease investor day on Thursday, the group said the residential pre-sales book of $5.2 billion is expected to settle over the next three to four years and it provides strong earnings and cash visibility over the medium term.
Lend Lease's chief executive Steve McCann said urban regeneration sites form the majority of the portfolio and provide delivery flexibility to match market timing and there is a strong balance sheet position and capital management.
Craig James, chief economist at CommSec said home building is at record highs, but it has by no means peaked.
"In the latest quarter, work had yet to start on a record number of homes that have previously been approved for construction. In fact the backlog is 20 per cent higher than the former record high," Mr James said.
"The home building boom is mirroring the former engineering construction boom but the benefits are more evenly spread. There are more homes being built in Australia at the moment (over 183,000) than at any point in the past."
Yet finding the sites to keep fuelling the developments for big and small investors remains the tough part. Some are being helped through the rezoning of land by local councils, while other lots are coming from new private families and neighbourhood syndicates.
One of the most recent was at St Leonards, when JLL sold a superlot of homes for a combined $66 million. The area had been rezoned by the Lane Cove Council.
Another deal is by a consortium of private individuals, who are selling a medium density amalgamated "R4 high density" residential site in Jannali, a southern suburb of Sydney.
It is a site area of 4143 square metres, with the land holding comprising five detached residential dwellings, in Mitchell Avenue and Sutherland Road and is being marketed with price expectations north of $12 million.
Adviser on the deal, director of Savills residential site sales, Stuart Cox, said the five neighbours got together to sell the site, where the zoning will allow a developer a maximum building height of five storeys.
Mr Cox said developers are now scouring suburbs where high residential zoning is in place and offering to buy homes in a "superlot" deal.
"We were approached by the five families to formulate a plan for them, after they had a knock on the door from many developers, prompted by the recent rezoning of the area," Mr Cox said.
He added it was becoming more prevalent for clusters of neighbours to sell in one lot to take advantage of the strong demand from developers.
A private family has also appointed Savills to market 59 Park Road in Burwood. Occupying a site area of about 1833 square metres, it is zoned medium density and comprises three detached dwellings with approval already achieved for a boutique residential development.
"With Sydney's shortage of housing and rising prices, demand for the inner west had dramatically increased which will result in developers keen to snap up this opportunity," Mr Cox said.
